data.stimulus:
TASK 1: THE STAGES OF THE WRITING PROCESS: DEFINITIONS

Below are the main stages of the writing process. Match the definition with the stage.

value: Reflecting on the work so that changes might be made
Carefully evaluating the work to find mistakes and make corrections
Making the work available for others (e.g. uploading to AULA)
The thinking, planning and research stage
When you begin to write

data.stimulus:
TASK 2: THE STAGES OF THE WRITING PROCESS - ORDER

Now, can you put each of the stages of the writing process into the order in which you should complete them?

value: This is where you put any raw (unprocessed) data,  survey results, extra graphs, maps, diagrams etc. that are either too large, or not important enough to include in your main discussion.
This is a summary of the report as a whole. It also often provides implications for the future or some suggestions based on the findings.
This is a short summary of the full report  designed to give busy 'executives' a quick overview of the key points. It is similar to an abstract, which is found in general academic papers.
This section talks about the wider context of the report. It provides the background information and outlines the report's structure.
This is a full list of all the books, websites, journals etc that you have referred to in your report.  These resources are the places where you found evidence for your ideas and arguments.
This where you discuss your process and gathering of data. Usually it includes the method you used to find the information needed. Then you describe what was done with the data found.
This is a list of all parts of the report, organised by headings and page numbers.  It helps the reader quickly see what is included in the report and how to find it.
This part includes the basic information about the report such as the title and the author.

TASK 4: TYPICAL ORDER OF REPORT SECTIONS

Can you order the different parts below in the order you think they should appear?
